newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan to tighten bank capital requirements.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan to tighten bank capital requirements.

text.p: State Bank of Pakistan moves to tighten capital requirements could inhibit the growth of banks with low capital bases and big loan portfolios, bankers said on Tuesday.
The central bank has sent a circular asking commercial banks to submit within three months their current equity positions and minimum capital requirement, factoring in risk-weighted assets.
The circular, received by Reuters on Tuesday, said this was a step towards enforcing internationally accepted standards on capital adequacy on banks incorporated in Pakistan.

Bankers said this could restrict lending or force banks to raise their capital base to stay within the capital adequacy ratio. State banks, most of which have large non-performing portfolios or have very liberal lending policies, would probably be the hardest hit, they added.

The U.S.-based Moody's Investors Services Inc in October assigned not prime long- and short-term bank deposit rating of B2 and a financial strength rating of E to three Pakistani state-run banks. It said they were suffering from poor asset quality, inadequate capital and low profitability.

Analyst Waheed Hasan of KASB & Co said stricter lending regulations in respect to capital adequacy would require banks to conform to the internationally accepted capital standards of the Basle-based Bank for International Settlements. "The new standards will necessitate a risk-adjusted capital adequacy, that is, capital as a percentage of risk-weighted assets, of a minimum of eight percent," he said.
A foreign banker said most Pakistani banks now calculate capital adequacy as a percentage of total demand and time liabilities, without factoring in risk-weighted assets.

The risk-adjusted capital adequacy ratio of most state-owned commercial banks currently averages around three percent, while most foreign and some new private banks are well above eight percent, said the banker, who asked not to be named.

If the central bank strictly enforces the eight percent risk-adjusted capital adequacy requirement, growth for banks will become increasingly difficult unless they raise fresh capital, retain earnings or cut back on lending, he said.

Hasan said most private banks already had large capital bases, but more stringent measures would inevitably favour well-capitalised foreign banks and some private ones, including Faysal Commercial Bank and Askari Bank.
